												As soon as I loaded this game up, I knew exactly what I was in for. Developed by Reiza Studios, the same folks behind the excellent Game Stock Car 2013 (Extreme now) and Formula Truck 2013 series of games, this is pretty much the same thing, but on the Brazilian stock car circuit. While not familiar with the Brazilian circuit myself, I thoroughly enjoy the aforementioned games, and anyone else that is familiar with those will feel right at home as well. This is mainly the reason that I am able to write this review with such little play time on this at the moment! So on to the gameplay! Once you're behind the wheel of either of three different car manufacturers (for now anyway), you'll see the familiar gMotor 2 engine used with these games, from the HUD to the ever-so-lovely shift/rpm gauge. Of course, these can be turned off (thankfully), which gives you a more realistic sim experience, if that is your cup of tea. And yes, you can change the view from the default cockpit! This is found in the Options > Display menu. There are a multitude of other settings that can be changed as well, from the number of cars seen on-screen at once to graphical settings. Most gamers with mid to high range machines can naturally max out these settings, as the graphics are not quite up to the same standards as Asetto Corsa and the likes. But, to me anyway, they look pretty good right out of the box, so to speak. This can also be said for the car handling physics, which are the same as other entries from Reiza Studios. And that is to say that they are some of the best that I have experienced in any racing game to date. Again, those that have played the games I mentioned know what I am referring to.In summary, if you've played the other games Reiza has offered, you know what you're in for, and will feel right at home once you're in the game. If you're even remotely interested in racing games that are more of a simulation, then you should definitely give this a try. And heck, even if you don't like racing games, give it a try anyway. After all, how can you go wrong with a free game, especially one of this magnitude. What are you waiting for, add it to your Steam library right now!!!

												Overall, it's a 6.5/10I can see it was at least inspired by GTR2, as it shares a lot of design choices. But it just falls short when compared.There are 4 different cars in the entire game, each with 2 different liveries. But they all feel the same.there are also 6 different tracks in the entire game, each with it's own feel to them. Nothing bad to say here.Options have been made well, there's a lot to change, controls, audio, display, and also difficulty of the game and rules of the races.And then there's the driving physics. None of these cars have ever spun on me, even with every driving assist off. They just feel as if they were FWD, is that supposed to be that way? Other than that, clutch works, brakes do lock, and You do lose control in certain situations, but it's way too easy.Same goes to the rival AI, once passed they do nothing to get their position back, and even before You pass them they seem like they were just moving obstacles on the road.Graphics are... not that bad actually, the contrast etc is fairly well balanced, but everything else is just not there. True, there are working real-time shadows of the cars and the track but... that's it. No real-time car reflections, they're just reflecting the skybox (which isn't any good either, just about 20 small clouds on the sky), no motion blur, no depth of field, nothing! It's the middle of 2015, what were you thinking?Sound is nice, You can hear everything happening around You, Cars do sound a little different but that's it, nothing spectacular again.Long review short, it's an average game when compared to other racing "simulators" out there, but from what I've seen, it's a good way to get into "arcade-simulator racing" as I call it. There aren't many cars to master, and they all feel the same so it's not a huge hop to change a car, the tracks aren't too hard to master, the AI isn't too hard and unforgiving, etc etc.So if You're new to the simulator genre, have an old computer which can't run modern games and a steering wheel do get it. It's for free so You can find out if You're going to like simulator racing or not. But if You do, please do get GTR2 and find some mods for it because that is the best way to get into "hardcore simulator racing". It's from 2005 so Your PC will run it, and it has a damn well written physics engine.

												PEOPLE GIVING MARCAS A NEGATIVE RATING MUST BE COMPLETELY BONKERS OR COMPLETELY SIMPLE...JUST DISGUSTING TO SEE THIS FINE FREE SIM RACER GET A MIXED REVIEW!If you are on a tight budget - there is simply no better sim racer you can find with such a complete single player championship experience, only raceroom experience comes close.There is absolutely no reason for people who are into racing not to like what Copa Petrobras de Marcas has to offer FOR FREE. The only reason this game is free is because Brazil's largest oil company Petrobras is paying the bill. Marcas is a promotional game built on a quality sim engine, by people who know how to make this engine shine better than the original programmers.You get a FULL TC championship, with the same great handling that comes with Reizas Game Stock Car series.If you have a FFB steering wheel you are in for a treat, as Reiza's Stock Car series has been universally recognized as having one of the best driving models in the business. The graphics are crisp and functional, without unnessessary eye candy (check SweetFX*), so the game can be played on most mid range machines at the highest graphical settings.I was actually happy that the Marcas content was recently added to the Stock Car Extreme game, as it is one one my favorite Reiza classes to drive - being front wheel driven they require a different style. FWD is another detail some negative reviews seem to miss when they discuss handling.As for the comment on driving views - there are many camera views (!), in and outside the car.Before posting negative reviews, take a little time to check the set up possibilities, controls etc, and you'll find that almost anything can be set up. Same for FFB, it can be tweaked to near perfection. At best any negatives given on these issues show a lack of looking for the proper settings - read stupidity of the reviewer.Most of the negative comments seem to come from people who are expecting an arcade racer, with basic one size fits all ez mode, game pad support, game pad friendly handling and "eye candy" visuals.Unfortunately by doing so they completely miss the point - as non target audience of this game - and trash the game accordingly.Pearls before swine I'm tempted to say.....The graphics are GOOD, nice and crisp SIM STYLE, instead of the on steroids Michael Bay kind you find in most arcade racers.Get a good FFB wheel, take some time to set up this game - my Logitech Driving Force GT requires NEGATIVE FFB to work correctly, you have to know that and deal with it. These are really essential requirements, just like installing the SweetFX* shaders to get optimal visuals.Learn how to drive with the free copa game and soon you'll be buying Stock Car Extreme for all its other classes and tracks. Want something really different, get Formula Truck. I own the original non-Steam versions of Reizas games, including the older GSC2012 - still cool, still on the hdd and I still play them.Summery- arcade racers move on (please, and stop reviewing)- get a good ffb wheel (essentiel with race sims)- take some time to tweak your settings (also essentiel, no one size fits all in sims)- install SweetFX (...some eye candy)- have fun RACING (the whole point)- give Marcas and Reiza some well deserved love!*The post processing effects you see in videos and screenshots are not standard, but can be easily installed. SweetFX - takes less the a couple of minutes to set up.http://www.racedepartment.com/downloads/sweetfx-reiza-settings-for-gsc-extreme-formula-truck-2013.3482/

												The simple and honest FACT about this game is, that it IS infact just rFactor1.  With a rearranged and revamped UI skin. The UI is so annoying and confusing to navigate to accomplish whatever tuning or changes you wish to make.  Loading out onto the track was like a joke. It screamed GTMAX world touring car mod (a rFactor user made mod) from 2011. Same Toyota, however this Focus version is new, seen this Lancer before.   Although these modders make a better default cockpit view. Its more like looking through a person with two eyes , than that narrow perspective♥♥♥♥♥rFactor "I must have only one eye" FOV. The controls by far, hands down, are a billion times more understandable and appreciated over rFactors♥♥♥♥♥♥for sensory feed back.   It seems like rFactor was geared towards idiots with logitech wheels, and not really followed by people with actual quality made devices.   As if the modder community just are a bunch of blow hards.  I do play rFactor  as a die hard fan, since it came out. But what I say is true.     This game without even touching any settings I chose to set out onto the track to see how "factor" like it was, and was proven wrong.  I was so happy to see that my first turn, that i said to myself "this is just about how i would steer if I were sitting in this car" actually gave the car the direction I wanted. Though being an rFactor fan, it makes me wonder if the settings we see and the choices that are configured in the .PLR file are set with some options that are in place to create that superb handling. 												With extensive experience in just about every Sim since the original Microprose Grand Prix games, includng time in earlier iterations of GSC, I really only needed half an hour of hotlapping to know exactly what you get with tis title.This is solid racing title, based and built on a tried and true, if ageing engine by a studio witha great reputation.And it is free.Having read some of the negative reviews, I have only come to the conclusion that they have been written by those with limited sim experience, who believe that plugging in an xbox controller and expecting to be able to drive this is the way to go.No.Get a wheel. Otherwise you are gimping yourself of any drivability and you will miss out on just how good titles such as this can be.Control of your inputs, smooth accceleration, controlled braking, finesse in the steering is what these titles are designed for. Pressing A to go and X to stop is just...wrong.You get a handful of cars and tracks for your money...which is $0, and that gives you enough content to keep a driver satisfied for sometime. Learing how each car drives, and then mastering it whilst learning all the intricacies of a trackis what you do here. It is not a matter of "Grats Dude! You just drove 3 laps in Shiny Supercar A, not go take Extra Shiny Super Car B for a spin! Put it on Youtube!"Pro points:All content free.Nice cars.Good tracksTried and tested engine.Great FFBCons:Whilst engine is good, and you will get super high FPS, it is a touch dated. Bring this into a next gen engine and Sim drivers will need to clean the white stains off their undershorts.Thats about it for the cons really.Titles such as this, for free, and others you can get pretty cheap these days, such as GTR2, the Race series, Rfactor 1 are still very enjoyable, great to drive and extrememly entertaining.If you are new to simming and looking for titles to cut your teeth before investing more heavily, and you have a half decent FFB wheel, get this. Then go buy Stock Car Extreme.

												The simple and honest FACT about this game is, that it IS infact just rFactor1.  With a rearranged and revamped UI skin.  Once you pass the first screen its painfully obvious what you are playing because no matter how you skin it, rFactor, stands out from its other clones like Race 07 and all of its variants.   The time favored menu options are still here.  Now the dead giveaway for me was the garage and its tuning options. The UI is so annoying and confusing to navigate to accomplish whatever tuning or changes you wish to make.  Loading out onto the track was like a joke. It screamed GTMAX world touring car mod (a rFactor user made mod) from 2011. Same Toyota, however this Focus version is new, seen this Lancer before.   Although these modders make a better default cockpit view. Its more like looking through a person with two eyes , than that narrow perspective♥♥♥♥♥rFactor "I must have only one eye" FOV. The controls by far, hands down, are a billion times more understandable and appreciated over rFactors♥♥♥♥♥♥for sensory feed back.   It seems like rFactor was geared towards idiots with logitech wheels, and not really followed by people with actual quality made devices.   As if the modder community just are a bunch of blow hards.  I do play rFactor  as a die hard fan, since it came out. But what I say is true.     This game without even touching any settings I chose to set out onto the track to see how "factor" like it was, and was proven wrong.  I was so happy to see that my first turn, that i said to myself "this is just about how i would steer if I were sitting in this car" actually gave the car the direction I wanted.       Excellent job guys. That alone is something to cheer about.  Though being an rFactor fan, it makes me wonder if the settings we see and the choices that are configured in the .PLR file are set with some options that are in place to create that superb handling.  Such as the fact that I cannot do anything about my infant drivers weak♥♥♥♥♥neck and his floppy loppy head banging around in the cockpit.  That♥♥♥♥♥♥is so wrong for one god damn reason. Yes G forces will batter your head from side to side, but, our amazing "anti skip technology" built in to our eyes, prevents us from having that unuseable sight of vibration.  Eyeballs let us look to the side without moving our heads. They allow the head to move without the area we are viewing to pan tilt or skew whilst our heads move along dang near any axis.     If my noodle neck driver could just hold his head still, (and option in all other games using this sim engine) it would be so much more fun to play.  But as  I inspected the games files I am to belive they acomplish their handles by using a slightly different approach. And I think its that they use the games physics engine in a different way. I believe this game bases the cars handles off of the drivers head physics, versus the other games having the .HDV file, the SUSP.pm, the , tires.tbc, and a few other components to configure how your car would feel on the track.      Whatever it is, great job.Questionable though I just find this game after its makers get bought out.You guys going to do a clone port of rFactor 2?That would be awesome if you keep improving the steering experience.  :D
